stem: The nurse is caring for a 68-year-old male patient admitted with acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). Review the patient information and identify the findings that indicate the patient is experiencing fluid volume overload. Click on those findings.

rationale.correct: Elevated blood pressure (160/90 mmHg), elevated heart rate (110 bpm), elevated respiratory rate (28), decreased oxygen saturation (90% on 2L nasal cannula), bibasilar crackles, 3+ pitting edema in lower extremities, jugular vein distention (JVD), Weight Gain of 5kg. These findings are indicative of fluid volume overload in the patient with ADHF. Elevated blood pressure and heart rate are compensatory mechanisms. Crackles indicate fluid in the lungs. Edema and JVD are signs of increased venous pressure.

mnemonic.title: DAMN I'M FULL of fluid
mnemonic.expansion: Dyspnea, Ascites, Moist Lung Sounds, Neuro changes, Increased BP, Muscle weakness/edema, Fluid volume overload.

rationale.incorrect: Normal laboratory values (Na, K, Cl, Hemoglobin, Hematocrit) and medications administered (Furosemide) do not directly indicate fluid volume overload. BUN and creatinine levels may be elevated but not directly correlated without other information.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus on individual vital signs without considering the overall clinical picture. They might incorrectly focus on lab values that are within normal limits or misinterpret the significance of the medications.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of analyzing trends and patterns in vital signs and correlating them with physical assessment findings. Remind students to prioritize assessment data over interventions in this particular question.

clinicalPearls: BNP (B-type natriuretic peptide) is a hormone released in response to ventricular stretching. Elevated levels are indicative of heart failure.
Daily weights are crucial for monitoring fluid status in patients with heart failure.
Assess for orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea as indicators of fluid overload.

itemContext.sbar: S: Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old male admitted at 03:00 today with ADHF. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He reports increasing shortness of breath and lower extremity edema over the past week. B: He was diagnosed with heart failure 2 years ago and is on furosemide 40mg PO daily. He missed several doses this week. A: At 07:00, his vital signs are: BP 160/90 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 28, SpO2 90% on 2L nasal cannula. He has bibasilar crackles, 3+ pitting edema in lower extremities, and JVD. He is anxious and restless. His current weight is 90 kg, up from 85 kg last week. O: I have administered furosemide 40mg IV stat per order and notified the provider of his condition.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 03:00: BP 150/85 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 92% on room air, Weight 85kg. 07:00: BP 160/90 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 28, SpO2 90% on 2L nasal cannula, Weight 90kg.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 138 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, BUN: 35 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL, BNP: 800 pg/mL, Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL, Hematocrit: 42%, Albumin: 3.2 g/dL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Furosemide 40mg PO daily (Home Medication), Furosemide 40mg IV STAT (07:00), Oxygen 2L per NC

distractorRationale.K: 4.2 mEq/L: This is a normal potassium level and does not indicate fluid volume overload.
distractorRationale.BUN: 35 mg/dL: BUN is elevated, however, without creatinine levels being significantly elevated it is not definitive enough to indicate fluid overload.
distractorRationale.Cl: 100 mEq/L: This is a normal chloride level and does not indicate fluid volume overload.
distractorRationale.Na: 138 mEq/L: This is a normal sodium level and does not indicate fluid volume overload.
distractorRationale.Hematocrit: 42%: This is a normal hematocrit level and does not indicate fluid volume overload.
distractorRationale.Oxygen 2L per NC: Oxygen administration addresses hypoxemia, which can be a consequence of fluid overload but is not a direct indicator of the overload itself.
distractorRationale.Albumin: 3.2 g/dL: Albumin is slightly decreased. This can be related to fluid overload but on its own, it is not an indicator.
distractorRationale.Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL: This is a normal hemoglobin level and does not indicate fluid volume overload.
distractorRationale.Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL: Creatinine is slightly elevated, however, without BUN levels being significantly elevated it is not definitive enough to indicate fluid overload.
distractorRationale.Furosemide 40mg IV STAT (07:00): This medication is a diuretic and its presence does not indicate current fluid volume overload, but rather an attempt to manage it.
distractorRationale.Furosemide 40mg PO daily (Home Medicatio: This medication is a diuretic and its presence does not indicate current fluid volume overload, but rather an attempt to manage it.
